moves.1. e4: I mated my first 1968 on Pogo, but I've gone on to win many blitz games against 18,19, & even 2000's here at GK on Blitz brain. Which goes to show that chess players skilled at Correspondence chess aren't necessarily as skilled at Blitz chess!
moves.1... c6 2. Nf3 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. h3: pre-empting the Bg4 pin, which is ok in my book since black has no developed pieces yet.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Bb5: Attacking while developing is almost always favorable to non-attacking development.
moves.7... Nf6 8. d4 Bd6 9. Bg5 a6 10. Bxc6 bx: White retracts the Bishop to h4 in hopes of a kingside weakening pawn push of g5
moves.15... f5 16. Ne5: Placing the Knight on an advanced post.
moves.16... O-O 17. Nf4: If NxN then white wins a pawn.
moves.17... Nxg3: Black chooses the free pawn and a simulteanous attack on the f1 rook.
moves.18. Nfg6: White coaxes black into a seemingly innocent exchange except white is breaking into the enemy camp.
moves.18... Nxf1 19. Qh5: Trap! white sacrafices the rook for the initiative & kingside attack!
moves.20... Kxf8: ?! under the time pressure black lost track, 20...Qxf8 21. Qg6  Kh8 22. Nf7  Qxf7 23. Qxf7 also loses black's queen, but atleast holds out longer.
moves.21. Qf7#: ## mate & the rook sacrafice was worth it.
